awd_titl_txt: The Role Of Resource Control In The Development Of Social Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Mitch Hendrickson, at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and his international collaborative team, is undertaking research on the role of iron production in the expansion of medieval states, with specific focus on the Angkorian Khmer Empire in Cambodia. Iron has long been viewed as an important catalyst for societal development yet few studies have effectively demonstrated evidence of changes in the scale of production or the impact that sudden access to high quality sources had on agricultural, architectural and military activities. Archaeology offers critical new insight into the way that iron was made, distributed and consumed over time as well as identifying the type of political-economic relationships between the state and local stake holders who lived around major resources. Fundamental to this investigation is how and why do major sources suddenly become a critical part of state development? New technologies and increased access are two important factors enabling control over resources that were often known but left untouched for hundreds of years. Parallel processes are witnessed today within the oil and gas industry and the expansion of China?s global resource interests across Asia and Africa.
Dr. Hendrickson?s team will investigate whether intensification and control of industrial activities were responsible for vast and sudden imperial expansion in the past. The geographic focus of the project is the Phnom Dek region in central Cambodia, the largest iron ore source available to the Angkorian Khmer Empire. The research team comprising archaeologists, archaeometallurgists, paleobotanists, and geologists will record the spatial and temporal history of industrial production and the relationship between the state consumers and local producers over a period of five hundred years. Excavation and intensive survey of smelting sites will identify critical changes in production technology and corresponding shifts in the quantity and quality of iron used for tools and weapons. The impact of this industrial history will be examined on two levels. First, what type of control did the state exert over the groups responsible for producing iron? Second, is there a direct correlation between increased production and major architectural building episodes and military campaigns undertaken by the Khmer Empire? The results will provide a dynamic history of resource management and political process that will become a benchmark for understanding the successes and failures of states and their impact on manufacturing communities. In addition to providing new opportunities for education and student training this project will generate important regional databases on metallurgical technology, the archaeomagnetic intensity curve of the earth, and industrial forest management that will be generally available and have broad, immediate scientific significance.

por.por_cntn:
Political expansion in the form of external conquest or internal consolidation is arguably the most dynamic stage in the life cycle of premodern states and empires. This phase of often sudden societal growth is traditionally linked to acts of charismatic rulers, bureaucratic policies or religious mandates and often limited to discussion of control over two essential resources, food and labor. The Industries of Angkor Project (INDAP) argues that the ability to undertake large programs of monumental construction or military expansion must also consider the impact of rapid and intensified access to other critical material resources and technologies used by the state.

Focussing on the Angkorian Khmer Empire, the most extensive and influential state in premodern mainland Southeast Asia (9th to 15th c. CE), INDAP undertook a comprehensive, multidisciplinary investigation of the role of iron to facilitate imperial goals of expansion. Iron is an invaluable material for weapons for military campaigns and tools for quarrying and building in stone. Our international team specifically sought to identify a chronological correlation between increasing evidence of iron production and the permanent switch to, and increased construction of, sandstone temples in the Angkor period. These temples were key markers of political power in the Khmer world and their reliance on sandstone as a building material is unique within Southeast Asia. Extensive field surveys and excavations around Phnom Dek iron source, literally translated from Khmer as the ?Iron Mountain?, in northern Cambodia was coupled with laboratory analysis of iron artifacts and iron waste products, economic plant remains, and radiocarbon dating to address these questions. The results allow us to conclude that the intensity and scale of iron production witnessed around Phnom Dek between the 11th and 13th centuries correlated with sandstone temple building construction in the capital of Angkor. Our study also demonstrated that these iron smelting communities, who are presumed to be related to an ethnic minority known to produce iron in the region today, actively participated in economic exchange with Angkor and were not forced to produce iron for the Empire.

 

During the course of the NSF grant, our project produced several new discoveries. We documented an iron production landscape extending over 200km2 (77mi2) that was in use for at least 1300 years. Our excavations at the Tonle Bak site uncovered the first in-situ remains of iron smelting furnaces in Cambodia. The size and form of these furnaces allows us to reconstruct the potential output of iron and understand how the massive mounds of iron production waste were created in the landscape. We also identified the first definitive evidence of long-term occupation associated with premodern iron production in mainland Southeast Asia. This contrasts with a global, historical trend where iron smelting was conducted away from settlements and on a part-time basis. The team also developed a new field methodology using a portable X-Ray Fluorescence instrument to document chemical differences indicating shifts in smelting ?recipes? used by iron communities over time around Phnom Dek. Finally, our collaborative work with geoscientists obtained the first record of the strength and fluctuations in the earth?s magnetic field for Cambodia between the 11th and 13th centuries. The results showed that, contrary to long-held views, the earth?s magnetic field was subject to sudden and acute fluctuations.

Our grant supported archaeological training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students based in the United States, Cambodia, and Australia. The metallurgical chemistry, plant and charcoal fuel results will become part of regional and global databases that will help to address questions of origins, evolution and exchange. Beyond academic interests, the results provide opportunities to preserve undocumented or forgotten aspects of Cambodia?s culture heritage. In addition to the map of new iron production sites, the furnace bases discovered at Tonle Bak used allowed the team to conduct an experimental smelt to see how iron was actually produced during the Angkor period. INDAP?s research also featured as a primary focal point in a documentary for the Science Channel series entitled Unearthed: Lost Temples of the Jungle in June 2017.
